Award.AwardTitle: Standard Grant: Perflourinated Chemicals: The Social Discovery of a Class of Emerging Contaminants

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

This project investigates the social discovery of per-fluorinated chemicals (PFCs), which are hazardous yet widely used in industrial production. They are an unusual class of chemicals with significant widespread, low-level consumer exposure, important potential climate change emissions, and identified contaminated communities exposed to high levels of contamination. Specifically, this project will examine scientific, regulatory and advocacy action to restrict the use of PFCs. It uses a social discovery approach, which explains the growing awareness of a previously unrecognized or poorly understood social problem, disease, condition, environmental hazard, or other social phenomenon. Examining PFCs as a class of chemicals, the proposed research will investigate the emergence of lay awareness, scientific research, government involvement, media coverage, litigation, and advocacy. The results of this project will provide a greater understanding of why there is a lack of data about the risks of most in-use chemicals. Following on other social scientific studies of chemicals, this work can encourage a more precautionary approach in chemical regulation by identifying and analyzing the consequences of delayed and incomplete restriction of hazardous chemicals. It will also aid in toxics reduction and green chemistry, and it will directly benefit public awareness by disseminating research findings to scientific, advocacy, governmental, and occupational groups. This research will highlight the need for chemical manufacturers to move toward safer chemicals.

Technical Summary

This project will provide a thorough understanding of PFCs as a case study for emerging contaminants: how they are used and regulated, how science and activists respond to these contaminants, and why certain groups choose to take up the issue of PFCs. This will contribute to a sociological understanding of how people interact with a contaminated environment through a comparison of site-specific and ubiquitous chemical exposure; to the sociology of risk, by recognizing how the origins of risk can shift without necessarily decreasing the levels of risk; and science studies about how scientific knowledge is created, communicated, and used to inform policy. This project will contribute to the growing number of social science studies on chemical policy, allowing for comparison across different social science studies of chemicals. This research is also significant in combining those broader chemical policy issues with site-specific research on contaminated communities? experience. Research questions to be addressed in the project include the following. How were the dangers of PFCs discovered in the 1970s and re-discovered in the 2000s? How have major contamination episodes impacted the awareness, regulation, and research related to PFCs? What have been the successes and failures of advocates for banning or regulating the use of PFCs in industrial production and in household and consumer products? What competing approaches to risk assessment and risk management are used by corporate PFC producers, regulatory agencies, scientists, affected residents, environmental health organizations, and academic scientists?

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PFAS Project team of 10 researchers: faculty, postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduates has worked to make known the extent and health effects of PFAS contamination by publicly tracking new cases in real-time; aiding community groups and local and state governments in remediation, research, and regulatory action; engaging with journalists to publicize the issue; giving conference and webinar presentations to diverse audiences; organizing national conferences; and acting as bridge-builders between activists, social movement organizations, scientists, journalists, water utilities, legislators, and regulators.

Our 9 publications are in top journals: New Solutions, Environmental Sociology, Environmental Science & Technology, Social Studies of Science, the Journal of Exposure Science & Environmental Epidemiology, and Journal of Health and Social Behavior. Several have had direct policy and regulatory relevance. Our Social Studies of Science article on chemical regulation and industry secrecy was quoted at a Senate Hearing on 'The Local, State, and Federal Response to the PFAS Crisis in Michigan' (U.S. Senate Committee on Homeland Security & Governmental Affairs 2018). Additionally, our paper on scientific decisions and social and political influences over the risk assessment process that were used to develop state and federal drinking water guideline levels for PFOA and PFOS received numerous requests from regulators and academics. In response, we presented findings from that paper during two webinars: one for academic and clinical researchers, and one for environmental and health advocates. PI Brown was the only social scientist signatory to the "Madrid Statement," a consensus statement on PFAS contamination published in Environmental Health Perspectives, the world's leading environmental health journal.

We have presented this research every year at the annual meetings of the American Sociological Association. Additional conference presentations were given at the Association of American Geographers, the Society for Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry (North Atlantic), the Interstate Technology & Regulatory Council, Rutgers University, the University of Warwick (UK), and the National Academy of Science. We also organized the 1st and 2nd National PFAS Conferences in 2017 and 2019, which brought together hundreds of people studying on PFAS in academia and government agencies, residents of PFAS-impacted communities, state and federal regulators, firefighters, lawyers, journalists, and industry representatives. We received a $6,000 and $35,000 conference grants from the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences for those conferences, which showed many environmental health scientists and government officials that STS, sociology, and other social sciences have much to offer them, and has led them to engage with those disciplines to gain fuller understandings of PFAS and other chemical issues.

We established the PFAS Project website (www.pfasproject.com), an extensive compendium of data that is updated almost daily with news stories and science advances. As part of this website, we developed the technical infrastructure to track, visualize, and engage stakeholders in contamination events across the country and abroad. The PFASProject.com website serves as an important repository of data on PFAS, including a major Contamination Site Database that is the only such database in existence. While the tracker began with just 88 sites, it has greatly expanded and as of June 2019 contains 213 sites. In the absence of systematic local, state, and federal testing and reporting on PFAS contamination, the Contamination Site Tracker has been a driving force for social discovery and awareness, and for holding government and industry accountable.

In partnership with the Environmental Working Group, we developed and published an interactive map of PFAS contamination to visually represent data from the Contamination Site Tracker as well as EPA water testing data. The map was released in June 2017 and was covered in over 35 media outlets around the country, with stories in such prominent outlets as Time, Huffington Post, and USA Today. As of May 2019, the map includes 610 locations of PFAS contamination, and continues to expand. We continually receive queries from residents in communities who previously were unaware of local PFAS contamination, and from other researchers and consultants who use the database.

The PFAS materials in Project Toxic Docs (www.toxicdocs.org) is a major contribution to that unique archive of industry and regulatory documents.

The project provided extensive training for undergraduate students, PhD students, and postdoctoral fellows. It supported our lead research assistant Lauren Richter's 2018 dissertation and provided in-depth research experience to eight undergraduates, two additional doctoral students, one MPH student, one nursing student, and two postdocs. We completed 80 interviews with people who have worked on all aspects of PFAS.

Above all, this project has contributed to PFAS remediation by providing data that promotes reduced use of the persistent, toxic and bioaccumulative chemical class of PFASs, and hence reduce their presence in humans, other animals, drinking water and food chains. This project has contributed to public health by examining the literature showing human health effects of PFASs and the potential for regulatory action and corporate changes that can reduce those risks.
